beats.reasoning: On the intro downbeat the track is low‑energy and the lyric sets a calm, cool mood; a subtle wave on a single light group gives gentle motion and a cool wash without overwhelming the start, fitting the 60‑70% sync and gradual build guidelines.
At ~1% of the track, the intro is calm and building tension. No VFX or heavy motion; keep breathing room to allow gradual build.

At beat 3/85 the track is in the very early intro (~2% of the song), with low energy and no dramatic moments yet. Following professional rules, we keep the lighting minimal to build tension and avoid overwhelming the vocals, so this beat remains a breathing room with no active effects.

At the very beginning of the track (≈4% in) the energy is only medium and the section is still part of the intro/verse build. To follow the 60‑70% sync rule and keep the mood calm, a single moving‑head light with a gentle rotate motion, a cool static color, and a subtle ping‑pong intensity creates tension without overwhelming the vocals.

This beat falls early in the intro, where the energy is medium and vocals start. Following the intro guidelines, we use a subtle moving head with wave motion and a cool static color to build tension without overwhelming the quiet atmosphere.

At ~6% of the track the intro is still building; medium energy with high‑band emphasis warrants a gentle wave motion to support the bass line without overwhelming the vocals. A cool, static color wash with low‑intensity wave effect keeps the mood subtle and allows room for later build‑up.
Beat 7/85 is in the early intro (~7% of the track) with only medium energy and no dramatic lyric cue; following the 60‑70% sync rule we leave breathing room to build tension gradually.

At ~8% of the track, the intro is still building tension with medium energy but no strobe or heavy VFX. A rotating single light with a cool static color and spectrum‑based intensity adds subtle motion while keeping the atmosphere calm.

Beat 9/85 falls in the early intro, a low‑energy build‑tension section. We use a gentle wave on a single moving head to add subtle motion without overwhelming the atmosphere, keeping VFX off and colors cool to maintain the intro mood.

Beat 10/85 falls in the early verse, moderate energy and lyrical content. To support vocals without overwhelming, a subtle Wave motion on a single moving head (key 2) with a warm static color and alternating intensity keeps the stage lively yet restrained, following the 60‑70 % sync rule.

Beat 11/85 falls in the early verse, medium energy with high‑band emphasis, ideal for a subtle supportive wash. A single moving head rotating keeps the groove without overpowering vocals, using a warm static color and spectrum‑based intensity to match the vocal tone.

Beat 12/85 falls in the mid‑verse with medium energy and a high‑band focus; a gentle wave on a single moving head offers rhythmic support for the vocal line while keeping the lighting understated, in line with verse‑supporting rules.

At 13/85 (~14% of the track) we are in a verse with medium energy and high‑band emphasis.  The lyric is vocal support, so a gentle wave motion with a warm static color and subtle intensity pulsing keeps the light present without overpowering the vocals, following the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 14 falls in the early verse where energy is medium and the lyric line is supportive; we use a gentle rotating motion on a single‑head group to keep the stage alive without overwhelming the vocals, following the 60–70% sync rule and keeping VFX off for calm sections.

At ~17% of the track this verse is still building, but a subtle motion on beat 15 will keep the light field alive without overpowering the vocals. A single moving head with a gentle wave and ping‑pong intensity supports the high‑band energy while staying under the 60‑70% sync rule.

This beat falls mid‑verse with medium energy and low brightness; a gentle, supportive motion keeps the vocals clear without overwhelming the section. A single moving head with a subtle rotate motion, warm static color and ping‑pong intensity provides breathing room while still adding texture.
Verse with medium energy and vocal emphasis; a gentle wave on a single moving head supports the lyric without overwhelming the mix, keeping sync at ~60‑70% while respecting the 19% song position.

Beat 18/85 falls in the early verse with moderate energy and high‑band emphasis. To support vocals without overwhelming, a single moving head performs a gentle rotate with a warm static color and a wave‑intensity pattern, giving subtle motion and dynamic light while keeping the section restrained.

Beat 19/85 falls in the middle of the verse, with medium energy and high‑band emphasis. To support the vocals without overwhelming them, we use a subtle LaserFan effect on a multi‑light group with a warm static color and alternating intensity for gentle movement.

Beat 20 falls in the early verse, medium energy and high‑dominant. To support vocals without overwhelming, a gentle wave motion on a single moving head provides subtle motion and color, keeping the mix balanced.

Beat 21 falls in the verse with medium energy and no bass emphasis; a subtle rotating wash from a single moving head supports the vocals without overwhelming the section, aligning with the 60‑70% sync rule and verse‑style restraint.

Beat 22/85 falls in the middle of a medium‑energy verse with no key lyrical shift; professional practice keeps verses subtle to support vocals. To maintain breathing room and avoid over‑saturation, this beat is left empty.

Beat 23/85 falls in the mid‑verse with medium energy and high‑dominant bass, so a subtle rotating moving head supports the vocals without overwhelming. A single‑light group with gentle motion, warm static color and alternating intensity keeps the energy alive while leaving room for breathing space.

Beat 24 sits on the off‑beat of an early verse with medium energy and mid‑band dominance; a subtle rotating wash supports the vocals without overpowering the section, in line with the 60‑70% sync rule and verse‑style restraint.

Beat 25 is a downbeat in the middle of the verse with medium energy and a high‑frequency dominant band. To support the vocals without overpowering, a single moving head performs a gentle wave motion with a warm static color and matching wave intensity for subtle yet engaging light.

Beat 26 falls on the second beat of a bar during the verse where the energy is medium and vocals are present. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, a subtle MotionEffect is appropriate—Wave motion (Motion 3) with a warm static color (Color 1) and a gentle PingPong intensity (Intensity 2) provides support without overpowering the vocal line.

Pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and lyric content – we add a subtle wave motion on a single moving head to increase tension, plus a gentle laser fan for dynamic texture, keeping intensity moderate and avoiding VFX until the drop.

At beat 28/85 (~32% of the track) the song is in a pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and mid‑band focus, so we use moderate motion to gradually raise intensity without hitting full drop levels. A LaserCone on the multi‑light group provides a sweeping visual cue, while a Wave on the single‑light group echoes the bass line; both use complementary color and intensity effects to support the vocals without overwhelming the mix.

At beat 29 the track is in the pre‑chorus build‑up; energy is medium but high‑frequency content rises, so a subtle laser effect adds forward momentum without overpowering the vocals. The beat is part of the 60‑70 % sync window, giving breathing room while still escalating intensity.

At 35% of the track this beat sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up. Energy is medium with a high‑band emphasis and vocals are present, so we use a subtle rotating wave on a single moving head to gradually increase intensity without overwhelming the listeners. No VFX or strobe is used to keep the build‑up feeling organic.

Beat 31 marks the early pre‑chorus; we’re building intensity but not yet at the chorus drop, so a subtle laser motion is appropriate. The high‑band energy and presence of vocals call for a synchronized LaserCone with color cycling and wave‑intensity to support the rising energy while keeping the section restrained.

During the build‑up phase (≈37 % of the track) the energy is medium with a high‑bass focus and vocals present; a subtle LaserFan with wave intensity enhances the motion without overpowering the mix. VFX are reserved for drops, so none are used here.

Beat 33/85 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency vocals. A laser cone on the multi‑light group provides a subtle, high‑band accent that syncs with the melodic line while keeping the intensity moderate to maintain the gradual rise. The static warm color and alternating beam intensity support the vocal without overwhelming the section.

Beat 34/85 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up; energy is medium and vocals are present. A subtle rotating motion on a single moving head with a warm static color and ping‑pong intensity keeps the section dynamic without overwhelming the vocals, following the 60‑70% sync rule and gradual build‑up principle.

At beat 35 the track is in a pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy but high‑band emphasis and active vocals; a subtle laser cone adds excitement without overstating the calm section. Adding a single multi‑light group keeps the 60‑70% sync rule while supporting the rising intensity.

Beat 36/85 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑band emphasis; a subtle wave motion on a single light supports the vocal line without oversaturating the mix. This keeps the 60‑70% sync rule and allows gradual intensity increase toward the chorus.

At ~43% of the track the build‑up to the chorus is reaching its peak, so we add motion to support the vocals and a subtle laser to raise intensity without a drop. The single light uses a Wave motion with a ping‑pong color and wave‑intensity to mirror the rising bass, while the multi‑light laser cone adds a bright beam with ping‑pong intensity for extra drama. No VFX is used because this is a pre‑chorus, not a drop.

Beat 38 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency vocals; a subtle laser effect will raise intensity without over‑strobing, keeping the 60‑70% sync rule. A single multi‑light laser fan with random per‑beam color and wave intensity supports the rising energy and enhances the vocal line.

Beat 39 falls in the mid‑chorus where energy peaks but is still medium‑intensity; we use lasers and moderate motion to accentuate the vocal line, avoiding VFX to keep the feel controlled. 60–70% sync means a few active groups here, so we light the multi‑beam arrays and a single moving head with dynamic motion.

Beat 40/85 lands on the downbeat of the chorus, a high‑energy drop where the vocalist repeats the line. According to the 60‑70% sync rule and professional conventions, we activate a VFX burst, synchronized laser cone/fan and a rotating single‑head to accent the dramatic moment while keeping the mix balanced.

Beat 41/85 falls in the chorus drop (~48% of the song) with high‑energy, high‑frequency vocals and a bass‑heavy backdrop. To support the vocal punch, a laser fan (multi‑light) provides rhythmic motion with a dynamic color wash, while a simultaneous VFX burst adds visual flair. This keeps the 60‑70 % sync rule and avoids over‑stimulation.

Beat 42/85 falls near the chorus start (~49% song). The energy is medium but the high‑band dominance invites a moderate light build‑up. A single moving head with a wave motion and a multi‑head laser cone provide dynamic motion without overwhelming the vocals, following the 60‑70% sync rule and keeping VFX for later drops.

Beat 43/85 sits in the chorus/drop where energy peaks; medium energy with high dominant tones and active vocals calls for dramatic lighting. A simultaneous VFX burst (group 0) punctuates the moment, while two multi‑beam lasers (groups 4 and 5) sync with the bass and melody, providing motion and color without over‑saturating the mix.

Beat 44/85 lands in a chorus drop with a high dominant frequency and a key lyric line; professional practice calls for a dramatic yet balanced visual that accentuates the high energy while preserving breathing room, so we activate a synchronized laser cone and a wave motion on a single head.

At beat 45/85 the track is in the chorus section (~52% song length) with medium energy but high‑dominant frequencies and vocal lines, making it a prime moment for dramatic lighting. Using a laser cone on the multi‑light group provides a sweeping visual that syncs with the melody, while a rotating single‑head adds dynamic motion to keep the audience engaged without over‑saturating the beat.

Beat 46/85 lands in the chorus drop with high‑frequency energy. To hit the 60‑70% sync target, I enabled a VFX group for simultaneous pyrotechnics, two laser groups (cone and fan) for the high‑band excitement, and two single‑head groups with rotating/rotating motion to support the vocals. This mix gives a balanced, dramatic look while respecting the 60–70% rule.

Beat 47/85 sits in the chorus/drop region (~55% of the track) with a high‑frequency, bass‑driven energy cue and vocal emphasis. To hit the peak moment while keeping 60‑70% sync, we activate a simultaneous VFX wave on the VFX group, a laser cone on the multi‑light group, and a moving‑head wave on a single‑light group, providing a layered, dynamic visual impact without over‑saturating the beat.

At 56% of the track this beat sits in the chorus/drop, a high‑energy, vocal‑heavy moment. We trigger a VFX burst for dramatic impact, sync a laser cone with a color‑varying beam array for visual energy, and add a rotating single head to accent the bass hits, keeping the 60‑70% sync rule while providing breathing room elsewhere.

Beat 49 falls within the chorus/drop (~57% of the track) where energy peaks.  We add a synchronized laser cone (multi‑light) and a rotating moving‑head for dynamic motion, plus a VFX group for a brief simultaneous effect on the drop. To keep 60‑70% sync while offering breathing room, we activate a VFX group for simultaneous firework effect, a multi‑light laser cone to accent the high‑frequency melody, and a single‑light wave motion to support the vocal line. All constraints are respected: VFX group has no motion/color/intensity, laser group uses LaserCone with dynamic color and wave intensity, and single light uses a wave motion with static color and ping‑pong intensity.

Beat 65/85 falls in a verse‑mid section with medium energy and vocal focus; a subtle Wave motion on a single moving head provides support without overwhelming the lyrics, aligning with the 60‑70% sync rule and maintaining contrast.

At ~90% of the track the song is winding down into an outro. The beat has medium energy but still carries vocals, so a subtle, calm motion keeps the audience engaged without overwhelming the fade. At the final 2% of the track the energy has dropped to medium‑low and the dominant band is mid. At ~99% the track is winding down; energy is medium but brightness low. A subtle laser fan keeps the visual field alive without overstimulating. The effect is modest, maintaining a calm atmosphere while respecting the 60–70% sync rule.

Beat 85/85 is at the very end of the track, low energy, mid‑band, and the lyrics are still present. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and the outro guidelines, this beat should remain quiet to allow a calm fade‑out without overstimulating the audience.
